metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: The appellant's application for registration of the word mark "COCK" under Class 28 of the NICE classification was rejected by the learned Senior Examiner of Trademarks.
The rejection was based on the existence of two identical marks registered for similar or allied goods, belonging to Mr. A.S. Chinna Nadar and Mr. Lokesh Kataria.
The appellant argued that the goods for which the "COCK" mark was sought to be registered were distinct from the goods for which the existing marks were registered.
The existence of a prior registered device mark "COCK" for "amorces or paper caps for toy pistols" was cited as a ground for rejecting the appellant's application.
The appellant contended that the water and colour pistols, guns, and sprayers made by them were toys and had no connection with fireworks or guns, despite their similar shape.
The learned Senior Examiner's objection was based on the similarity between the goods, despite the appellant's argument that the goods were different in substance.
The rejection of the appellant's application was appealed, with the appellant submitting written submissions and arguing that the learned Senior Examiner's objection was misconceived.
The respondent, the Registrar of Trademarks, filed written submissions in response to the appeal, and the matter was heard by the High Court of Delhi.

The court considered the distinction between the goods for which the "COCK" mark was sought to be registered and the goods for which the existing marks were registered, in determining whether to allow the appeal.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agrawal vs. Registrar of Trade Marks**

**Background:**

The appellants, Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agrawal, filed an application (No. 3757855) to register the word mark "COCK" under Class 28 of the NICE classification for "water and colour pistols, water and colour guns, water and colour sprayers, being toys included in Class 28". The application was rejected by the Senior Examiner of Trade Marks, citing two existing marks that were identical and used for similar or allied goods. The rejection was based on the marks registered in favor of Mr. A.S. Chinna Nadar (Chinna Nadar) and Mr. Lokesh Kataria.

**Legal Issues:**

1. Whether the mark "COCK" can be registered for water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers under Class 28, given the existing registrations of identical marks for similar or allied goods.
2. Whether the goods for which the appellant seeks registration (water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers) are similar or allied to the goods for which the existing marks are registered (amorces or paper caps for toy pistols).

**Arguments:**

The appellant argued that:

1. The existing mark registered in favor of Chinna Nadar is a device mark, which clearly indicates that the registration is for amorces and not for water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers.
2. The goods for which the appellant seeks registration (water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers) have nothing in common with amorces, which are used in toy pistols to produce a firing sound.
3. The appellant's goods are used to spray colors during festivals like Holi, whereas amorces are used in toy pistols to produce a firing sound.

The respondent (Registrar of Trade Marks) argued that:

1. The existing mark registered in favor of Chinna Nadar is identical to the mark applied for by the appellant.
2. The goods for which the appellant seeks registration are similar or allied to the goods for which the existing mark is registered.

**Court Findings:**

The court noted that the objection raised by the Senior Examiner was based on the existing registration of the mark "COCK" in favor of Chinna Nadar for "amorces or paper caps for toy pistols". The court observed that the appellant's goods (water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers) are distinct from amorces, which are used in toy pistols to produce a firing sound.

**Decision:**

The court allowed the appeal, setting aside the order of the Senior Examiner rejecting the appellant's application for registration of the mark "COCK" under Class 28. The court held that the appellant's goods (water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers) are not similar or allied to the goods for which the existing mark is registered (amorces or paper caps for toy pistols). The court directed the Registrar of Trade Marks to reconsider the appellant's application for registration of the mark "COCK" under Class 28.

The decision suggests that the court recognized the distinctiveness of the appellant's goods and the lack of similarity between the appellant's goods and the goods for which the existing mark is registered. The court's decision allows the appellant to proceed with the registration of the mark "COCK" under Class 28, subject to further consideration by the Registrar of Trade Marks.

1. 
The appellant is aggrieved by order dated 4th February 2021, 
passed by the learned Senior Examiner of Trademarks in the office of 
the Registrar of Trademarks, whereby Application No. 3757855 of the 
appellant has been rejected by the learned Senior Examiner. 
 
2. 
Written submissions by way of response to the appeal have 
been filed by the respondent. I have heard Mr. Miglani, learned 
Counsel for the appellant and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, 
learned Counsel for the respondent. 
 
Facts 
 
3. 
Application No. 3757855 was submitted by the appellant for 
registration of the word mark “COCK” under Class 28 of the NICE 
classification as adopted by Rule 20 of the Trademarks Rules 2017,

for “water and colour pistols, water and colour guns, water and colour

the goods in respect of which the impugned mark was sought to be 
registered were pistols in the nature of “pichkaris” (water guns), used 
in festivals such as Holi for spraying colours. He submits that, even if 
akin in shape to guns, the water and colour pistols made by the 
appellant have nothing in common with fireworks, with which, 
traditionally, guns are associated.  They, therefore, are guns merely in 
form, not in substance.   
 
4. 
Consequent to filing of the aforesaid application by the 
appellant, the learned Senior Examiner in the office of the Registrar of 
Trademarks, vide First Examination Report (FER) dated 13th March 
2018, objected to the grant of registration for the appellants COCK 
mark, citing two marks which, according to him, were identical and 
used for goods which were similar or allied to the goods in respect of 
which registration was sought by the appellant.  The proprietors, in 
whose favour the said marks were registered, were Mr. A.S. Chinna 
Nadar (“Chinna Nadar”, hereinafter), Sivakasi and Mr. Lokesh 
Kataria, Gurgaon. 
 
5. 
Of these, at the time when the FER was issued, the COCK mark 
of Mr. Lokesh Kataria was under objections. Subsequently, the 
application of Mr. Kataria stands rejected by the learned Registrar.  As 
such, the objection of the learned Senior Examiner, predicated on the 
COCK registration granted to Chinna Nadar alone survives for 
consideration.  This position has already stands noted in the order 
dated 23rd May 2022 passed in the present proceedings. 
 
6. 
On receiving the aforesaid FER, the appellant, vide reply dated

2nd April 2018, submitted that the objection of the learned Senior 
Examiner was misconceived, as the COCK brand registered in favour 
of Chinna Nadar was for “amorces or paper caps for toy pistols”, 
whereas the appellant was seeking registration of the COCK mark for 
water and colour pistols, guns and sprayers used to spray colours 
during festivals such as Holi.  It was also pointed out that the mark 
which stood registered in favour of Chinna Nadar was the device mark 
 which clearly indicated that the registration was for amorces 
and for no other goods. The registration sought by the appellant was, 
on the other hand, for toy pistols used to spray colours, which had 
nothing in common with amorces.  An “amorce”, as Mr. Miglani 
points out from the dictionary, is a percussion cap for a toy pistol. 
Elsewhere, the expression “amorce” is defined as “a firework which is 
a percussion cap designed for use in toys, which comprises of paper 
envelope containing a dot of impact sensitive pyrotechnic composition 
and which forms part of a roll”. 
 
7. 
I may note, here, that, in India, such rolls, which are fitted in toy 
pistols, are often used by children on the occasion of festivals such as 
Diwali. These rolls are often mounted on pistols between the striking 
surface and the body of the pistol so that, when the pistol is cocked 
and fired, due to the impact of the strike, a small spark is emitted with 
a noise imitative of a bullet being fired.  Amorces are available in rolls 
or in individual pieces.   
 
8. 
The appellant’s objection was not accepted by the learned 
Senior Examiner who has, by the impugned order dated 4th February 
2021, rejected the appellant’s application.  The impugned order reads

thus: 
“Instant mark is phonetically and visually identical to the 
conflicting marks which is mentioned in the search report and also 
they are well in prior use in respect of the similar nature of goods 
which sought by the applicant. The applicant is the well subsequent 
user among the conflicting mark user period. In view of these 
grounds, the Tribunal has opined that the applicant has deliberately 
chosen the subject mark in an effort to ride upon the goodwill and 
reputation of the conflicting marks. Applicant has no bona fide 
adoption of the subject mark in respect of the applied goods. 
Further, the allowance of the subject mark is patently mala fide 
since the mark has been dishonestly adopted by the applicant hence 
the applicant cannot claim to be the proprietor of the subject mark 
under Section 18(1) of the Act. Allowance of the subject mark is 
adversely affecting the interest of the public; it would lead to 
confusion as it is more than likely, due to imperfect recollection 
that the average buyer may confuse the applicant’s mark “COCK” 
as the conflicting owner’s product sold under “COCK”. In view of 
such similarities between the nature of the marks and their goods, 
the applicant’s trade channel and counters, there exists a strong 
likelihood of confusions on the part of the consuming public, 
including an association, as they are likely to assume and confuse 
that the applicant’s goods are connected or otherwise associated 
with the conflicting marks goods, when no such connection exists. 
Consequently, the members of the trade would no doubt, be under 
the mistaken belief that the applicant’s goods originate from the 
conflicting mark or that they have some trade connection or 
affiliation thereby causing irreparable loss and damage not only to 
the conflicting mark trade and business but also suiting erosion of 
distinctiveness hard earned by the conflicting marks. 
 
In addition to the facts of the subject application, I want to 
discuss the land mark case of Cadila Health Care Ltd. v. Cadila 
Pharmaceuticals1 wherein the Supreme Court has stated that in an 
action for passing off on the basis of unregistered trade mark 
generally the following factors have to be considered for deciding 
the question of deceptive similarity of marks: 
 
(a) 
The nature of the marks i.e. whether the marks 
are word marks or label marks or composite marks i.e. 
both words and label marks 
 
(b) 
The degree of resemblances between the marks, 
phonetically similar and hence similar in idea. 
 
(c) 
The nature of the goods in respect or which 
they are used as trade marks. 
 
(d) 
The similarity in the nature, character and 
                                          
1 AIR 2001 SC 1952

Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729

performance of the goods or the rival traders. 
 
(e) 
The class of purchasers who are likely to buy 
the goods bearing the marks they require, on their 
education and intelligence and a degree of care they are 
likely to exercise in purchasing and or using the goods. 
 
(f) 
The mode of purchasing the goods or placing 
orders for the goods, and 
 
(g) 
Any other surrounding circumstances which 
may be relevant in the extent of dissimilarity between 
the competing marks. 
 
Weightage to be given to each of the aforesaid factors 
depends upon facts of each case and the same weightage cannot be 
given to each factor in every case. 
 
Based upon the Supreme Court guidelines, the above 
mentioned seven factors are obviously applicable to this case. In 
order to avoid the opposition to the registration as well as passing 
off actions against the subject mark, the Tribunal is not ready to 
accept the subject mark for journal publication. 
 
In this position, I would like to enlighten the object of the 
Trade Marks Act, 1999. The said object is to provide for 
registration and better protection of trade marks for goods and 
services and for the prevention of the use of fraudulent marks. If 
the subject mark is allowed for registration, the object of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999 would be jeopardized and the purity of the 
Register will be affected. 
 
In view of the above said reasons, the Trade Mark 
Application is refused under sections 11(1)(a) and (b) of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999.” 
 
Rival Contentions 
 
9. 
Mr. Miglani submits that the impugned order is misconceived. 
The finding of the learned Senior Examiner that the use, of the COCK 
mark registered in favour of Chinna Nadar was for goods which were 
similar to those in respect of which registration was being sought by 
the appellant is, he submits, erroneous on facts.  The goods in respect 
of which the appellant was seeking registration, and the goods in 
respect of which the COCK brand stood registered in favour of  
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 6 of 13 
 
Chinna Nadar, he submits, are completely different.  
 
10. 
In fact, submits Mr. Miglani, the appellant stands registered for 
use of the COCK brand for colours since 1992.  The appellant had 
earlier been issued a legal notice dated 19th February 2018 by Sri 
Kaliswari Fireworks, of which Chinna Nadar was admittedly the 
Director, objecting to the use, by the appellant, of its COCK label.  
The appellant had replied to the said legal notice on 17th March 2018, 
submitting that, whereas the appellant’s COCK mark was used for 
Holi colours, gulal and like goods, Chinna Nadar’s mark was used for 
fireworks, sparklers, crackers, ground wheels, rockets, colour matches 
etc. Mr. Miglani points out that, on the said reply being submitted by 
his client, Sri Kaliswari Fireworks had, by its communication dated 
30th January 2019, expressed satisfaction with the reply of the 
appellant. 
 
11. 
The goods in respect of which the appellant was now seeking 
registration of the COCK brand are, submits Mr. Miglani, goods 
which are used for spraying the very colours in respect of which the 
COCK brand already stands registered in the appellant’s favour since 
1992.  Chinna Nadar has already expressed his satisfaction with the 
use of the said mark by the appellant for colours.  As such, he submits, 
the learned Senior Examiner acted unreasonably in refusing 
registration to the appellant, for the mark “COCK” in respect of water 
and colour pistols, guns and sprayers, under Class 28. 
 
12. 
Mr. Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the respondent, on the 
other hand, supports the impugned order.  He submits that the COCK 
mark registered in favour of Mr. A.S. Chinna Nadar is also used for 
toy pistols.  The mere fact that toy pistols in which the said amorces 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 7 of 13 
 
were used, were normally used in Diwali, whereas the toy pistols for 
which the appellant was seeking registration are used in Holi and like 
festivals, he submits, cannot make a substantial difference or justify 
interference with the impugned order which is well-reasoned.  He 
submits that the goods in respect of which registration was being 
sought by the appellant, and the goods in respect of which the COCK 
brand was registered in favour of Chinna Nadar were both used in 
festival celebrations.  As such, he submits that both the items would 
be available from similar small shops and that it was a matter of 
common knowledge that festivals such as Durga Pooja, spraying of 
colours and fireworks both took place.  As such, Mr. Vaidyanathan 
submits that the learned Senior Examiner cannot be faulted in refusing 
registration to the appellant’s mark. 
 
Analysis 
 
13. 
I have heard learned Counsel and perused the material on 
record. 
 
14. 
Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act provides “relative grounds 
for refusal of registration”, as against “absolute grounds for refusal” 
envisaged by Section 9.  The grounds for refusal, contained in Section 
11, essentially relate to earlier marks registered in favour of someone 
else, or for which an application is pending with the office of the 
Registrar of Trademarks.  We are concerned with Section 11(1)2. 
                                          
2 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of –  
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services 
covered by the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods 
or services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 8 of 13 
 
15. 
Section 11(1)(a) prohibits registration of a trademark which is 
identical to an earlier trademark and used in respect of similar goods 
or services, whereas Section 11(1)(b) prohibits registration of a 
trademark which is similar to an earlier trademark and used in respect 
of identical or similar goods or services.  In either case, there must, 
additionally, exist a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, 
for registration to be refused under Section 11(1). The provision also 
clarifies that “confusion” would include likelihood of association with 
the earlier trademark. 
 
16. 
Having heard learned Counsel for both sides and applied my 
mind thereto, I am unable to subscribe to the view of the learned 
Senior Examiner that the goods, in respect of which registration of the 
COCK word mark was being sought by the appellant, were similar to 
the goods in respect of which the COCK device mark stood registered 
in favour of Chinna Nadar.  Mr Vaidyanathan’s submission that toy 
pistols are toy pistols, I feel, oversimplifies the issue.  The “guns”, or 
“pistols”, for which the appellant sought registration of the COCK 
mark, are guns or pistols merely in form, not in substance.  They emit 
neither heat nor light.  They are not, therefore, fireworks in any sense 
of the expression.  They emit – if one may use the expression – not 
fire, but its antithesis; water.  A gun which sprays water and a gun 
which emits a spark and, therefore, releases heat and light are about as 
alike as chalk and cheese.  The fact that they may both be used on 
similar occasions does not make them like, similar, or allied, even in 
ordinary parlance.   
 
17. 
The appellant seeks registration of the COCK word mark.  
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 9 of 13 
 
Chinna Nadar holds a registration for the 
 device mark.  
Chinna Nadar’s mark is a composite device mark which includes, 
apart from the words “COCK BRAND”, the word “AMORCES”.   
 
18. 
Besides, Chinna Nadar’s registration was specifically for 
“amorces or paper caps for toy pistols”.  As such, the mark was not 
even registered for toy pistols per se, but only for amerces used in toy 
pistols.  The appellant’s request for registration could not, therefore, 
have been refused on the ground that the COCK brand stood 
registered in favour of Chinna Nadar for toy pistols.  The “toy pistols 
are toy pistols” plea of Mr Vaidyanathan is really, therefore, 
irrelevant.  Chinna Nadar’s registration was for amorces.  Toy pistols 
which spray water cannot, howsoever much the imagination were to 
be strained, be likened to amorces.  Indeed, one would extinguish the 
other.   
 
19. 
This is not an infringement suit.  We are concerned, therefore, 
not with Section 29, but with Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act.  
Refusal of an application for registration is justified only if the 
grounds are relatable either to Section 9 or to Section 11.  Section 
11(1), as already noted, envisages refusal of registration only if, either 
(i) 
(a) 
the applicant’s mark and the earlier mark are 
identical and the marks are used for similar goods or 
services, or 
 
(b) 
the applicant’s mark and the earlier mark are 
similar, and the marks are used for identical or similar 
goods or services, and 
(ii) 
registration of the applicant’s mark would result in a a 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 10 of 13 
 
likelihood of confusion, or association with the earlier mark, on 
the part of the public. 
“Likelihood of confusion” is not to be easily presumed.  The nature of 
the goods and the class of their purchasers has to be borne in mind.   
 
20. 
The appellant’s COCK word mark and Chinna Nadar’s COCK 
device mark cannot, strictly speaking, be said to be identical.  That 
apart, mere identity or similarity of the marks is not sufficient to 
disentitle an applicant for registration under Section 11(1).  It has, 
additionally, to be shown that 
(i) 
the goods or services in respect of which the earlier mark 
stood registered or applied for, were identical or similar to the 
goods or services in respect of which registration was being 
sought, and 
(ii) 
registration of the mark in favour of the applicant would 
result in a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public. 
 
21. 
Registration of an “eligible” mark is a valuable commercial 
right.  Registration brings, in its fold, several inalienable entitlements; 
most importantly the entitlement to protection against infringement.  
Registration, where the mark is eligible therefor cannot, therefore, be 
refused.  An application for registration of a trade mark, therefore, can 
be rejected only if it falls strictly within the peripheries of the criteria 
envisaged by Sections 9 and 11 of the Trademarks Act. 
 
22. 
Viewed thus, for the following reasons, I am of the opinion that 
the appellant’s mark would be entitled to registration: 
 
(i) 
The appellant’s mark cannot be treated as identical or 
similar to the mark which already stood registered in favour of 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 11 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 11 of 13 
 
Chinna Nadar.  The appellant sought registration of the word 
mark COCK.  The mark registered in favour of Mr. A.S. Chinna 
Nadar was the 
 device mark, which contained, 
prominently, the words “COCK BRAND” above the figure of a 
strutting cock and, below that, the word “AMORCES”.  A 
person viewing the mark would, therefore, be made clearly 
aware of the fact that the mark was used only in respect of 
amorces and nothing else.  There could not, therefore, be said 
that there existed any likelihood of confusion, much less a 
possibility of Chinna Nadar’s goods being passed off as a goods 
of the appellant by reason of the registration of the appellant’s 
mark. 
 
(ii) 
That apart, amorces and toy spray guns used for spraying 
water and colours are neither identical or similar.  Chinna 
Nadar’s COCK brand was registered only for amorces; not even 
for toy guns.  Amorces are not used with spray guns which 
spray water or colour; indeed, water would extinguish the 
amorce and render it unusable.  Amorces are fireworks.  The 
appellant’s guns spray coloured water.  Fire cannot be likened 
to water.  The appellant sought registration of the word mark 
COCK for toy pistols or guns used for spraying coloured water 
during festivals.  They have nothing in common with toy pistols 
used in fireworks; much less with amorces used with such 
pistols.  The mere fact that, in some festivals, both may be used, 
is irrelevant.  Similarity, for the purposes of Section 11(1), has 
to be of the goods or services, not of the occasion of their user.    
The impugned order of the learned Senior Examiner has not 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 12 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 12 of 13 
 
considered this aspect or the difference in the nature of the 
goods for which the appellant sought registration, vis-à-vis the 
goods for which the COCK mark was registered in favour of 
Chinna Nadar.   
 
(iii) Further, there is little chance of any likelihood of 
confusion in the minds of public between the two marks, or 
likelihood of any association, by registration of the COCK word 
mark in favour of the appellant, with the rgistratioon of the 
 device mark in favour of Chinna Nadar.  As already 
noted, the appellant’s mark was being used in toy pistols which 
sprayed coloured water during festivals.  The 
 device 
mark registered in favour of Chinna Nadar was, on the other 
hand, used for amorces, which are in the nature of small 
fireworks.  It cannot, therefore, be said, in the absence of any 
material to indicate to the contrary, that the registration of the 
COCK word mark in favour of the appellant, as sought, would 
result in any likelihood of confusion in the minds of the public. 
 
23. 
None of the three criteria, which require cumulative satisfaction 
in order for an application for registration of a mark to be rejected 
under Section 11(1) of the Trademarks Act can, therefore, be said to 
be satisfied in the present case. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, it is not necessary for this Court to 
enter into the allegations of mala fide etc. which find place in the 
impugned order and which, in my opinion, ought not to have been 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 13 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 13 of 13 
 
returned without adequate evidence. 
 
Conclusion 
 
25. 
For the aforesaid reasons, I am unable to sustain the impugned 
order, which is accordingly quashed and set aside.  Application No. 
3757855 of the appellant would accordingly stand allowed in terms 
thereof.    
 
26. 
The appeal is, accordingly, allowed with no order as to costs.   
 
27. 
Consequential steps be taken by the learned Registrar in 
accordance with law.   
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 1, 2023

tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding was held in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. The case, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, involved an appeal by Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal against the Registrar of Trade Marks. The appellants were represented by Mr. M.K. Miglani, while the respondent was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar and others.

The dispute centered on the rejection of the appellants' Application No. 3757855 for registration of the word mark "COCK" under Class 28 of the NICE classification. The application was rejected by the Senior Examiner of Trademarks, citing identical marks registered by other parties, including Mr. A.S. Chinna Nadar and Mr. Lokesh Kataria.

The appellants argued that their goods, water and color pistols, also known as "pichkaris", were distinct from the goods associated with the other registered marks. However, the learned Senior Examiner's objection, based on the COCK registration granted to Chinna Nadar, remained for consideration.

The court heard oral submissions from both parties and considered written responses. The judgment, delivered on February 1, 2023, addressed the appeal and the objections raised by the respondent. The details of the decision are not provided in the given section, but the court's consideration of the case is outlined in the PDF document, which serves as the source for this summary.

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary: According to page 2 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the appellants, Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal, applied to register their "COCK" mark for "water and colour pistols, water and colour guns, water and colour sprayers" (Class 28). The Senior Examiner objected to the registration, citing two identical marks registered by Mr. A.S. Chinna Nadar and Mr. Lokesh Kataria. However, Mr. Kataria's application was later rejected. The objection based on Mr. Chinna Nadar's registration remains. The appellants argued that their water guns are not similar to fireworks-associated guns, but rather "pichkaris" used in festivals like Holi. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with a Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000729. Key dates include March 13, 2018 (First Examination Report) and May 23, 2022 (order passed in the present proceedings).

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021) is underway in the High Court of Delhi. The appellants, Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal, are seeking registration of the "COCK" mark for water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers used to spray colors during festivals like Holi.

The Registrar of Trade Marks rejected their application, citing a conflicting mark registered in favor of Chinna Nadar for "amorces or paper caps for toy pistols". The appellants argued that their mark is distinct, as it is for toy pistols used to spray colors, which is different from amorces. However, the Senior Examiner rejected this argument, stating that the marks are phonetically and visually identical, and the applicant is a subsequent user trying to ride on the goodwill of the conflicting mark.

The impugned order dated February 4, 2021, states that the allowance of the subject mark would lead to confusion among the public and cause irreparable loss to the conflicting mark's trade and business. The court is considering the facts of the subject application, including the potential for confusion and the distinctiveness of the marks. The PDF document provides a detailed account of the legal proceedings, including the arguments presented by both parties and the decisions made by the court. (Source: Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf, pages 1-4 of 13)

Miglani, argued that the objection by the Senior Examiner was misconceived. The COCK brand was registered for "amorces or paper caps for toy pistols", whereas the appellant sought registration for water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers. The appellant claimed that the registered mark was for a device, clearly indicating it was for amorces, and not related to the goods they sought to register. The Senior Examiner rejected the appellant's application on February 4, 2021. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with the Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000729. 7.

pistols, are often used by children on the occasion of festivals such as 
Diwali. These rolls are often mounted on pistols between the striking

and fired, due to the impact of the strike, a small spark is emitted with

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the Tribunal found that the applicant's mark "COCK" is phonetically and visually identical to existing marks, and its allowance would lead to confusion among consumers. The Tribunal cited the landmark case of Cadila Health Care Ltd. v. Cadila Pharmaceuticals, which outlined factors to consider for deceptive similarity of marks, including the nature of the marks, degree of resemblance, nature of goods, and similarity in nature and character. The Tribunal concluded that the applicant's adoption of the mark was not bona fide and was an attempt to ride on the goodwill and reputation of existing marks. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/000729. (Source: PDF page 4)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 4 of 13 
 
thus: 
“Instant mark is phonetically and visually identical to the 
conflicting marks which is mentioned in the search report and also 
they are well in prior use in respect of the similar nature of goods 
which sought by the applicant. The applicant is the well subsequent 
user among the conflicting mark user period. In view of these 
grounds, the Tribunal has opined that the applicant has deliberately 
chosen the subject mark in an effort to ride upon the goodwill and 
reputation of the conflicting marks. Applicant has no bona fide 
adoption of the subject mark in respect of the applied goods. 
Further, the allowance of the subject mark is patently mala fide 
since the mark has been dishonestly adopted by the applicant hence 
the applicant cannot claim to be the proprietor of the subject mark 
under Section 18(1) of the Act. Allowance of the subject mark is 
adversely affecting the interest of the public; it would lead to 
confusion as it is more than likely, due to imperfect recollection 
that the average buyer may confuse the applicant’s mark “COCK” 
as the conflicting owner’s product sold under “COCK”. In view of 
such similarities between the nature of the marks and their goods, 
the applicant’s trade channel and counters, there exists a strong 
likelihood of confusions on the part of the consuming public, 
including an association, as they are likely to assume and confuse 
that the applicant’s goods are connected or otherwise associated 
with the conflicting marks goods, when no such connection exists. 
Consequently, the members of the trade would no doubt, be under 
the mistaken belief that the applicant’s goods originate from the 
conflicting mark or that they have some trade connection or 
affiliation thereby causing irreparable loss and damage not only to 
the conflicting mark trade and business but also suiting erosion of 
distinctiveness hard earned by the conflicting marks. 
 
In addition to the facts of the subject application, I want to 
discuss the land mark case of Cadila Health Care Ltd. v. Cadila 
Pharmaceuticals1 wherein the Supreme Court has stated that in an 
action for passing off on the basis of unregistered trade mark 
generally the following factors have to be considered for deciding 
the question of deceptive similarity of marks: 
 
(a) 
The nature of the marks i.e. whether the marks 
are word marks or label marks or composite marks i.e. 
both words and label marks 
 
(b) 
The degree of resemblances between the marks, 
phonetically similar and hence similar in idea. 
 
(c) 
The nature of the goods in respect or which 
they are used as trade marks. 
 
(d) 
The similarity in the nature, character and

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court considered seven factors to determine the extent of dissimilarity between competing marks, including the nature of the goods, class of purchasers, and mode of purchasing. The Tribunal refused the subject mark for journal publication to avoid opposition and passing off actions. The Trade Mark Application was refused under sections 11(1)(a) and (b) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, to protect the object of the Act and the purity of the Register. The appellant's counsel, Mr. Miglani, submitted that the impugned order was misconceived, and the finding that the goods were similar was erroneous. (Source: PDF, Case No. C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000729)

(e) 
The class of purchasers who are likely to buy 
the goods bearing the marks they require, on their 
education and intelligence and a degree of care they are 
likely to exercise in purchasing and or using the goods. 
 
(f) 
The mode of purchasing the goods or placing 
orders for the goods, and 
 
(g) 
Any other surrounding circumstances which 
may be relevant in the extent of dissimilarity between 
the competing marks. 
 
Weightage to be given to each of the aforesaid factors 
depends upon facts of each case and the same weightage cannot be 
given to each factor in every case. 
 
Based upon the Supreme Court guidelines, the above 
mentioned seven factors are obviously applicable to this case. In 
order to avoid the opposition to the registration as well as passing 
off actions against the subject mark, the Tribunal is not ready to 
accept the subject mark for journal publication. 
 
In this position, I would like to enlighten the object of the 
Trade Marks Act, 1999. The said object is to provide for 
registration and better protection of trade marks for goods and 
services and for the prevention of the use of fraudulent marks. If 
the subject mark is allowed for registration, the object of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999 would be jeopardized and the purity of the 
Register will be affected. 
 
In view of the above said reasons, the Trade Mark 
Application is refused under sections 11(1)(a) and (b) of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999.”

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021) is underway in the High Court of Delhi. The appellants, Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal, are seeking registration of the "COCK" brand for water and color pistols, guns, and sprayers under Class 28. 

The appellants' counsel, Mr. M.K. Miglani, argues that the "COCK" mark is already registered in their favor since 1992 for use with colors, and that the goods for which they are seeking registration are used for spraying colors. He also mentions that the respondent, Sri Kaliswari Fireworks, had earlier objected to the use of the "COCK" label but later expressed satisfaction with the appellants' reply.

The respondent's counsel, Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, supports the impugned order, stating that the "COCK" mark registered in favor of Mr. A.S. Chinna Nadar is also used for toy pistols, and that the goods in question are used in festival celebrations, which could lead to confusion.

The court is considering Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, which provides relative grounds for refusal of registration. The decision will depend on whether there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public due to the similarity of the marks and the goods or services covered. (Source: "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000729)

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
According to page 7 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the respondent's counsel, Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, argues that the goods in question, toy pistols, are used in festival celebrations like Holi, similar to the COCK brand registered in favor of Chinna Nadar, which is used in Diwali. He submits that both items are available in similar small shops and that the learned Senior Examiner's decision to refuse registration to the appellant's mark is justified.

The court analysis refers to Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, which provides relative grounds for refusal of registration, including likelihood of confusion with an earlier mark. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with a neutral citation number of 2023/DHC/000729. The proceedings involve appellants Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal, and the respondent is the Registrar of Trade Marks. (Source: PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf")
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 7 of 13 
 
were used, were normally used in Diwali, whereas the toy pistols for 
which the appellant was seeking registration are used in Holi and like 
festivals, he submits, cannot make a substantial difference or justify 
interference with the impugned order which is well-reasoned.  He 
submits that the goods in respect of which registration was being 
sought by the appellant, and the goods in respect of which the COCK 
brand was registered in favour of Chinna Nadar were both used in 
festival celebrations.  As such, he submits that both the items would 
be available from similar small shops and that it was a matter of 
common knowledge that festivals such as Durga Pooja, spraying of 
colours and fireworks both took place.  As such, Mr. Vaidyanathan 
submits that the learned Senior Examiner cannot be faulted in refusing 
registration to the appellant’s mark. 
 
Analysis 
 
13. 
I have heard learned Counsel and perused the material on 
record. 
 
14. 
Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act provides “relative grounds 
for refusal of registration”, as against “absolute grounds for refusal” 
envisaged by Section 9.  The grounds for refusal, contained in Section 
11, essentially relate to earlier marks registered in favour of someone 
else, or for which an application is pending with the office of the 
Registrar of Trademarks.  We are concerned with Section 11(1)2. 
                                          
2 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of –  
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services 
covered by the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods 
or services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses Section 11(1) of the trademark law, which prohibits registration of a trademark that is identical or similar to an earlier trademark, causing likelihood of confusion. The case involves the registration of the "COCK" word mark for water guns, which was opposed due to an existing "COCK" device mark for fireworks. The court disagrees with the Senior Examiner's view that the goods are similar, stating that water guns and fireworks are fundamentally different. The appellant, Manu Garg, seeks registration of the "COCK" word mark, represented by Mr. M.K. Miglani. The respondent, Registrar of Trade Marks, is represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar. The case number is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with a neutral citation number of 2023/DHC/000729.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 8 of 13 
 
15. 
Section 11(1)(a) prohibits registration of a trademark which is 
identical to an earlier trademark and used in respect of similar goods 
or services, whereas Section 11(1)(b) prohibits registration of a 
trademark which is similar to an earlier trademark and used in respect 
of identical or similar goods or services.  In either case, there must, 
additionally, exist a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, 
for registration to be refused under Section 11(1). The provision also 
clarifies that “confusion” would include likelihood of association with 
the earlier trademark. 
 
16. 
Having heard learned Counsel for both sides and applied my 
mind thereto, I am unable to subscribe to the view of the learned 
Senior Examiner that the goods, in respect of which registration of the 
COCK word mark was being sought by the appellant, were similar to 
the goods in respect of which the COCK device mark stood registered 
in favour of Chinna Nadar.  Mr Vaidyanathan’s submission that toy 
pistols are toy pistols, I feel, oversimplifies the issue.  The “guns”, or 
“pistols”, for which the appellant sought registration of the COCK 
mark, are guns or pistols merely in form, not in substance.  They emit 
neither heat nor light.  They are not, therefore, fireworks in any sense 
of the expression.  They emit – if one may use the expression – not 
fire, but its antithesis; water.  A gun which sprays water and a gun 
which emits a spark and, therefore, releases heat and light are about as 
alike as chalk and cheese.  The fact that they may both be used on 
similar occasions does not make them like, similar, or allied, even in 
ordinary parlance.   
 
17. 
The appellant seeks registration of the COCK word mark.  
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:02.02.2023
17:45:24
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary: According to page 9 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the case of Chinna Nadar's registered device mark "COCK BRAND" with the word "AMORCES", which is specifically for "amorces or paper caps for toy pistols". The appellant's request for registration was refused due to this existing registration. However, the court argues that Chinna Nadar's registration was for amorces, not toy pistols, and that toy pistols that spray water cannot be likened to amorces. The court is concerned with Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, which envisages refusal of registration only if the applicant's mark is identical or similar to an earlier mark for similar goods or services. (Source: "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 9)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 9 of 13 
 
Chinna Nadar holds a registration for the 
 device mark.  
Chinna Nadar’s mark is a composite device mark which includes, 
apart from the words “COCK BRAND”, the word “AMORCES”.   
 
18. 
Besides, Chinna Nadar’s registration was specifically for 
“amorces or paper caps for toy pistols”.  As such, the mark was not 
even registered for toy pistols per se, but only for amerces used in toy 
pistols.  The appellant’s request for registration could not, therefore, 
have been refused on the ground that the COCK brand stood 
registered in favour of Chinna Nadar for toy pistols.  The “toy pistols 
are toy pistols” plea of Mr Vaidyanathan is really, therefore, 
irrelevant.  Chinna Nadar’s registration was for amorces.  Toy pistols 
which spray water cannot, howsoever much the imagination were to 
be strained, be likened to amorces.  Indeed, one would extinguish the 
other.   
 
19. 
This is not an infringement suit.  We are concerned, therefore, 
not with Section 29, but with Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act.  
Refusal of an application for registration is justified only if the 
grounds are relatable either to Section 9 or to Section 11.  Section 
11(1), as already noted, envisages refusal of registration only if, either 
(i) 
(a) 
the applicant’s mark and the earlier mark are 
identical and the marks are used for similar goods or 
services, or 
 
(b) 
the applicant’s mark and the earlier mark are 
similar, and the marks are used for identical or similar 
goods or services, and 
(ii) 
registration of the applicant’s mark would result in a a

nodes.title: Page 10
nodes.summary: According to page 10 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the likelihood of confusion between the appellant's COCK word mark and Chinna Nadar's COCK device mark. The court states that mere identity or similarity of marks is not sufficient to disentitle an applicant for registration under Section 11(1). Registration of a mark can only be refused if it falls within the criteria envisaged by Sections 9 and 11 of the Trademarks Act. The court is of the opinion that the appellant's mark is entitled to registration, as it cannot be treated as identical or similar to the already registered mark. This opinion is based on the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with a Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000729.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000729 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021  
Page 10 of 13 
 
likelihood of confusion, or association with the earlier mark, on 
the part of the public. 
“Likelihood of confusion” is not to be easily presumed.  The nature of 
the goods and the class of their purchasers has to be borne in mind.   
 
20. 
The appellant’s COCK word mark and Chinna Nadar’s COCK 
device mark cannot, strictly speaking, be said to be identical.  That 
apart, mere identity or similarity of the marks is not sufficient to 
disentitle an applicant for registration under Section 11(1).  It has, 
additionally, to be shown that 
(i) 
the goods or services in respect of which the earlier mark 
stood registered or applied for, were identical or similar to the 
goods or services in respect of which registration was being 
sought, and 
(ii) 
registration of the mark in favour of the applicant would 
result in a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public. 
 
21. 
Registration of an “eligible” mark is a valuable commercial 
right.  Registration brings, in its fold, several inalienable entitlements; 
most importantly the entitlement to protection against infringement.  
Registration, where the mark is eligible therefor cannot, therefore, be 
refused.  An application for registration of a trade mark, therefore, can 
be rejected only if it falls strictly within the peripheries of the criteria 
envisaged by Sections 9 and 11 of the Trademarks Act. 
 
22. 
Viewed thus, for the following reasons, I am of the opinion that 
the appellant’s mark would be entitled to registration: 
 
(i) 
The appellant’s mark cannot be treated as identical or 
similar to the mark which already stood registered in favour of

nodes.title: Page 11
nodes.summary: According to page 11 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the appellant sought registration of the word mark "COCK" for toy pistols or guns used for spraying colored water. The respondent, Registrar of Trade Marks, opposed the registration citing a similar mark "COCK BRAND" registered by A.S. Chinna Nadar for amorces (fireworks). The court argued that there is no likelihood of confusion between the two marks as they are used for different products (amorces and toy spray guns) and serve distinct purposes. The court also stated that similarity in goods or services is required for Section 11(1), not the occasion of their use. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with a neutral citation number of 2023/DHC/000729. The signing date of the document is 02.02.2023.

Page 11 of 13 
 
Chinna Nadar.  The appellant sought registration of the word 
mark COCK.  The mark registered in favour of Mr. A.S. Chinna 
Nadar was the 
 device mark, which contained, 
prominently, the words “COCK BRAND” above the figure of a 
strutting cock and, below that, the word “AMORCES”.  A 
person viewing the mark would, therefore, be made clearly 
aware of the fact that the mark was used only in respect of 
amorces and nothing else.  There could not, therefore, be said 
that there existed any likelihood of confusion, much less a 
possibility of Chinna Nadar’s goods being passed off as a goods 
of the appellant by reason of the registration of the appellant’s 
mark. 
 
(ii) 
That apart, amorces and toy spray guns used for spraying 
water and colours are neither identical or similar.  Chinna 
Nadar’s COCK brand was registered only for amorces; not even 
for toy guns.  Amorces are not used with spray guns which 
spray water or colour; indeed, water would extinguish the 
amorce and render it unusable.  Amorces are fireworks.  The 
appellant’s guns spray coloured water.  Fire cannot be likened 
to water.  The appellant sought registration of the word mark 
COCK for toy pistols or guns used for spraying coloured water 
during festivals.  They have nothing in common with toy pistols 
used in fireworks; much less with amorces used with such 
pistols.  The mere fact that, in some festivals, both may be used, 
is irrelevant.  Similarity, for the purposes of Section 11(1), has 
to be of the goods or services, not of the occasion of their user.

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal filed by Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal (Appellants) against the Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent). The appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021) challenged the impugned order rejecting the Appellants' application for registration of the "COCK" word mark.

The Court considered the differences in the nature of goods for which the Appellants sought registration, compared to the goods for which the "COCK" mark was registered in favor of Chinna Nadar. The Court noted that there was little chance of confusion between the two marks, as the Appellants' mark was used for toy pistols, while the device mark registered in favor of Chinna Nadar was used for small fireworks (amorces).

The Court concluded that none of the criteria under Section 11(1) of the Trademarks Act were satisfied, and therefore, the impugned order was quashed and set aside. The Appellants' application (No. 3757855) was allowed, and the appeal was granted with no order as to costs. The decision was made by Justice C. Hari Shankar on February 1, 2023. The PDF document, available as "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", provides the detailed court proceedings and decision.

The court noted that there is little chance of confusion between the two marks, as the appellant's mark was used for toy pistols, while the device mark registered in favor of Chinna Nadar was used for amorces (small fireworks). The court concluded that none of the criteria for rejecting an application for registration of a mark under Section 11(1) of the Trademarks Act were satisfied. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, with a Neutral Citation Number of 2023/DHC/000729, and was digitally signed by Kamla Rawat on February 2, 2023. (Source: Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. nodes.title: Page 13
nodes.summary: According to page 13 of the PDF "Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court concludes that the impugned order is quashed and set aside. The appeal, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2021, is allowed with no order as to costs. The Application No. 3757855 of the appellant is allowed in terms thereof. The decision was made by C.HARI SHANKAR, J on February 1, 2023. The Registrar is directed to take consequential steps in accordance with the law. The PDF source provides the Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000729, and the case was heard in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. The appellants, Manu Garg and Ratan Behari Agarwal, were represented by Mr. M.K. Miglani, Adv., while the respondent, Registrar of Trade Marks, was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC, and others.
